Observation Policy for Patients in ED /19021/1.2
Page  of
Introduction
This policy has been developed to ensure all patients attending the Emergency Department (ED) at Mid Essex Hospital Services NHS Trust have the required observations undertaken and recorded.

The observations undertaken will be specific to individual patients' needs, to ensure that the patient is clinically safe and cared for in the correct area and any variance is recognised in a timely manner to facilitate corrective action.
This policy sets out best practice for all Clinical Staff including Doctors, Nurses, Pre- Registration Nurses, HCA's and Student Nurses working in the ED.
When this policy states Clinical Staff it implies all of the above staff groups.
Roles and Responsibilities
It is the responsibility of the Nurse In Charge (NiC) and Emergency Physician in Charge (EPiC) of each shift to ensure that observations are undertaken and documented in accordance with this policy.
Any exceptional circumstances which may result in this policy not to be complied with as detailed point 2.3.

Major Incident, CBRNE Incident, and where the floor management team have escalated to senior management that the ED is clinically unsafe, should be immediately escalated by the Nurse in Charge to the ED Matron and Clinical Director and clearly documented along with the time it was done.
Out of hours this should be escalated to the Site Manager.
Training Requirements
Training will be part of the local nurse induction, staff training process.
This will be reviewed at annual appraisal.
Definitions

data.text: Scope of Policy
This policy applies to all patients over the age of 16 attending ED.

The only exclusion is patients with clinical minor injuries or streamed directly to the GP in ED where observations will be performed at the discretion of the Emergency Nurse Practitioner, Streaming Nurse, Minor's Nurse or Doctor.
All Nurses working within ED are expected to adhere to this policy.

Any ED Registered Nurse delegating the task of performing and recording observations to a doctor, another Registered Nurse/ Midwife, a Health Care Assistant or Student Nurse, must ensure they delegate effectively and are accountable for the appropriateness of the delegation. The Nursing and Midwifery Council Code (2018) requires that nurses and midwives must: -
Establish that anyone they delegate to is able to carry out their instructions.
Confirm that the outcome of any delegated task meets required standards.
Make sure that everyone they are responsible for is supervised and supported.
Policy Statements
All neurological observations will be accurately recorded and will consist of the following:-
Blood pressure, pulse, respiratory rate, temperature, pupil size/reaction, limb movement (upper/lower), blood oxygen saturation and Glasgow Coma Score (NICE CG176);

Patients who require additional observations due to their clinical need, will have these carried out at initial assessment. This must be accurately documented within the nursing notes. All patients attending ED will have an appropriate set of observations recorded according to their clinical need, all patients admitted to ED will have an assessment, which should include a basic set of observations (section
5.1) recorded within  minutes of arrival (except as in section 5.2);

Direct ambulance admissions will have a basic set of observations (see section 5.1) recorded at initial assessment or within 15 minutes of taking handover from the ambulance staff (except as in section 5.2);
All patients must have a basic set of observations recorded directly before transfer to another department or ward;

Using a systematic structure, such as those set out in all resuscitation and trauma courses, all patients should be assessed using an A, B, C, D, E approach. Each stage should be assessed and rectified before moving to the next stage;
The registered nurse caring for the patient is responsible to ensure that the NEWS2 score is recorded along with the appropriate observations based on patient's clinical need and location;
If any patient triggers on their NEWS2 score, then that nurse must follow the appropriate algorithm;
Patient escalation should be triggered by a single NEWS2 score ofor a combined score ofor more and the NiC and EPiC informed.
Adult Observations

The Mid Essex Hospital Services NHS Trust NEWS2 validated scoring system should be used for recording all adult observations and thus entered on to the Vitalpac system. A NEWS2 score will be calculated and recorded with every set of observations.

Frequency of Observations

The standard for patients in majors and resus is that 1 hourly observations are recorded until there is a documented medical management plan. Frequency of observations will be determined according to the patient's clinical need if changed from this initial emergency department standard.

Any change in frequency of observations will be agreed by the registered nurse looking after the patient in liaison with the nurse-in-charge, along with any doctor involved in the care of the patient. This decision and the name of the decision maker must be clearly documented in the Emergency dept. notes and must state the rationale for the change and Vital PAC system updated.

For those patients who trigger (a score of 5 or more, or a score of 3 in any of the observations undertaken) using the NEWS2 score, more frequent observations may be required as directed by the NEWS2 algorithm.

All ECGs recorded should be reviewed and signed legibly by a doctor in accordance with the ECG signoff in the ED policy. Further ECGs, and frequency, should be carried out based on the patient's clinical need and ECG changes/abnormalities. The frequency of repeat ECGs, along with rationale, and the name of the decision maker must be documented clearly in the Emergency Department notes.

BM recordings should be repeated hourly if outside normal range until recordings return to normal. Frequency should be increased or decreased based on clinical need and in liaison with nurse-in-charge and any doctor involved in the care of the patient.
All patients on a sliding scale insulin infusion must have hourly BM recordings undertaken and recorded.
All children/young people should follow the 08113 Diabetic Keto Acidosis (DKA) clinical Guideline regarding frequency of BMs.

All patients with head injuries or alcohol intoxication, presenting to the ED should have a baseline set of neurological observations performed at time of arrival (except as in section 5.2, and where it can be confirmed that both the mechanism and injury are both clinically minor in nature.)
If any significant head injury is suspected or the patient has a reduced level of consciousness, neurological observations should be performed and recorded in accordance with NICE CG176.

For patients presenting to the Emergency Dept. following Head Injury the minimum frequency of observations for patients with a GCS equal to  should be half-hourly for two hours, hourly for four hours, and then two hourly thereafter.
Should a patient with GCS equal to  deteriorate at any time after the initial two-   hour period, observations should revert to half-hourly and follow the original
frequency schedule (NICE CG176).
If any of the following examples of neurological deterioration occur then prompt urgent reappraisal by the ED doctor should be carried out, and the Nurse-In-
Charge informed:
Development of agitation or abnormal behaviour.
A sustained (that is, for at least thirty minutes) drop of one point in GCS.
Any drop of three or more points in the eye-opening or verbal response scores of the Glasgow Coma Scale, or two or more points in the motor response score.
Development of severe or increasing headache or persisting vomiting.
New or evolving neurological symptoms or signs such as pupil inequality or asymmetry of limb or facial movement. (NICE CG176 2014).
If either more frequent observations, or recommencement of observations is
required (patients who have been declared medically fit and may be awaiting social or psychiatric review), a basic set of observations should be undertaken and
recorded and reported to the Nurse-In-Charge.

It is the responsibility of the Named Registered Nurse to ensure the NiC and EPiC are made aware that the patient's condition has deteriorated and as such, observations have been recommenced. The reasoning for the recommencement or change in frequency must be clearly documented in the nursing notes.
Equipment
The equipment required to undertake and carry out the observations referred to within this policy includes:
An automatic noninvasive blood pressure recording machine;
A manual sphygmomanometer and stethoscope;
Disposable blood pressure cuffs (various sizes);
Disposable pulse oximetry leads;
A urinalysis machine or testing strips;
Blood glucose monitoring equipment;
A pen torch;
A thermometer;
An ECG recording machine;
A cardiac monitor;
A peak flow recorder;
Weighing scales;
Pregnancy testing kits.

It is the responsibility of the Emergency Senior Sisters /Charge Nurses to ensure adequate equipment / resources, as set out in section 9.1 are available and if not, this should be escalated to the Emergency Department Matron. Out of hours this should be escalated to the Clinical Site Manager.

It is the responsibility of the ED Matron to ensure that in liaison with the Service Manager for Emergency Care, funds are kept available to repair / maintain, or purchase equipment, so as safe levels of equipment listed in section 9.1 is available to use.
Infection Prevention
All staff should follow Trust guidelines on infection control by ensuring that they effectively decontaminate their hands between each patient they perform observations on.
All observation monitoring equipment should be decontaminated between each patient and disposable attachments used where supplied.

Where patients are high risk of infection, then disposable monitoring equipment should be used where available. After use, disposable equipment should be disposed of, and any non- disposable equipment should be decontaminated as per Trust policy before any further use.
Audit
It is the responsibility of the ED Matron to audit compliance with this policy and to review current equipment resources based on current patient attendance figures.

Compliance with this policy will be initially audited four weeks after implementation and continue six monthly post implementation by the ED Matron Any instances of non-compliance with this policy should be recorded on the Datix system as a risk event and investigated accordingly.
Departmental Audit in line with RCEM QIP for Vital Signs in Adults annually.
Approval and Implementation
12.1 Governance will upload the policy to the intranet and website after ratification. It is the responsibility of the author to notify key staff individually by e-mail.
